contextId.information: Peter speaks of peace as if it were an object that could increase in size or numbers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Peter speaks of a person who does not possess these qualities as if he is a field that will not produce a crop. This can be stated in positive terms. AT: "you will produce and be fruitful" or "you will be effective" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
contextId.quote: you will not be barren or unfruitful

contextId.information: Peter speaks of a person who does not possess these qualities as if he were a nearsighted or blind person because he does not understand their value. AT: "is like a shortsighted person who cannot see their importance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sees only what is near; he is blind

contextId.information: Here the word "stir" means to awaken someone from sleep. Peter speaks of causing his readers to think about these things as if he were waking them from sleep. AT: "to cause you to think about these things with a reminder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to stir you up with a reminder about these things

contextId.information: Peter speaks of his death as if he were leaving one place to go to another. AT: "after my death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

Peter speaks of Christ as the "morning star," which indicates that daybreak and the end of darkness is near. Christ will bring light into the hearts of believers, ending all doubt and bringing full understanding of who he is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the morning star rises in your hearts

contextId.information: The word "master" here refers to a person who owns slaves. Peter speaks of Jesus as the owner of people whom he has bought, the price being his death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Possible meanings are 1) "in chains in a very dark place" or 2) "in very deep darkness that imprisons them like chains." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The words "stains" and "blemishes" share similar meanings. Peter speaks of the false teachers as if they are stains on a garment that causes shame for those who wear it. AT: "They are like stains and blemishes on clothes, which causes disgrace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Right behavior that honors God is spoken of as if it were a path to follow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Peter speaks of people who live sinfully as if they are slaves to sin who need to be released from their captivity. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: people who try to escape ... promise freedom ... slaves of corruption

contextId.information: Peter speaks of a person as a slave when anything has control over that person, and that thing as the master of that person. AT: "For if something has control over a person, that person becomes like a slave to that thing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For a man is a slave to whatever overcomes him

contextId.information: Peter speaks of causing his readers to think about these things as if he were waking them from sleep. AT: "to cause you to think pure thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to stir up your sincere mind

contextId.information: Being persuaded to disobey God is spoken of as it were being led off the right path to follow. Deceitful or false teachings are spoken of as if they were someone who could lead another person off the right path. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
